Description: Terracotta figure of Isis, or isis-Hathor. Probably a representation of ‘Isis-Aphrodite anasyr(o)mene’ (also known as Isis-Bubastis), who is commonly depicted holding up the front of her tunic to show her pubic area. This example is broken at the waist, the bottom half missing. Her hair is parted in the middle and Isis-locks fall onto her shoulders; she wears earrings (?) and an enormous wreath with decorative elements, from which leaves fall like wide ribbons from the headdress. From the top of the wreath rises a large flaring kalathos (broken and mostly lost), decorated with an Isis-Hathor crown of cow’s horns and sun disc. The back is largely plain. A few traces of a white dressing are preserved (unless post depositional plaster). Hollow, made in a two-piece mould. Orange-brown Nile Delta silt fabric with abundant mica, quartz and some white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Close parallel from early 2nd century BC context in Tell Atrib (Szymańska 2005, no. 46). However other parallels have been dated between the 3rd to 2nd century BC and the Roman period (Dunand 1990, no. 360-1). Dunand, F. 1979. Religion Populaire en Égypte Romaine, Leiden. Dunand, F. 1990. Catalogue des Terres cuites gréco-romaines d’Egypte. Musée du louvre. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Paris. Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.131) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4598 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
